official-title.#text:
To amend the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act
		  of 1990 to require criminal background checks, inspections, and training of
		  child care providers.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Education and the
			 Workforce

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Child Care Criminal Background Check
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Child Care and
			 Development Block Grant Act of 1990
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990

text.#text:
The purpose of this Act is to assist States
			 in improving the overall quality of child care services in the State by
			 requiring national criminal background checks of child care providers that are
			 licensed by the State or that receive funds under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 658E(c)(2) of
			 the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658E/ss:c/p:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may waive for 1 fiscal year the application
				of this subparagraph to the State if the State demonstrates a good faith effort
				to comply with the requirements specified in this subparagraph and its
				inability to so comply.

continuation-text.#text:
At the
				request of a State, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658P/p:5/sp:B

text.#text:
require each eligible child care provider
				(excluding an eligible child care provider described in

to obtain from the State a comprehensive
				criminal background check of—

each individual
				who provides child care services;

each applicant
				selected for employment before providing such services; and

each family child
				care provider who provides or applies to provide such services; and

to refuse to
				employ, or continue to employ, an individual to provide such services—
if such individual was convicted of—
a crime of violence (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
				20101 of subtitle A of title II of the Violent Crime Control and Law
				Enforcement Act of 1994
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994/t:II/st:A/s:20101

text.#text:
to an eligible child without the
				supervision of an employee whose criminal background check satisfies the
				requirements of the subparagraph, pending receipt of such a criminal background
				check of such individual; and

to an eligible child with the supervision
				of an employee whose criminal background check satisfies the requirements of
				the subparagraph and for a period exceeding 90 days, pending receipt of such a
				criminal background check of such individual; and

carry out at the request of an eligible
				child care provider, as soon as practicable, a comprehensive criminal
				background check (at the State option for a fee not to exceed the actual cost
				to the State) of each employee of, and each applicant for employment by, a
				child care provider that is licensed by the State or receives funds provided
				under this subchapter by the State, and make the results of such check
				available to such provider and to such employee or applicant.

Certify that
				the State will—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) that is licensed by the State will be inspected not less
				frequently than at 3-month intervals.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658P/p:5/sp:B

text.#text:
The State shall certify that each eligible
				child care provider (excluding an eligible child care provider described in

40
				hours of training provided by an entity recognized by the State; and

annually 24 hours
				of training that includes CPR, first aid, recognizing child abuse, basic safety
				and health, and child behavior and
				development.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) that receives funds provided under this subchapter will
				receive not less than—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658P/p:5/sp:B

text.#text:
The State shall certify that each eligible
				child care provider (excluding an eligible child care provider described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by
			 adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 658I(b)(2) of the Child Care and
			 Development Block Grant Act of 1990
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658I/ss:b/p:2
Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990/s:658e/ss:c/p:2/sp:I

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall reduce by 10 percent the State allotment for
				the fiscal year following the fiscal year with respect to which noncompliance
				is
				found.

quoted-block-continuation-text.#text:
If a
				State fails to comply substantially with the requirements specified in

text.#text:
This
			 Act and the amendments made by this Act shall take effect 2 years after the
			 date of the enactment of this Act.
